journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Performance of triangle method for evaluating energy loss in vehicle collisions

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanics and Industrial Technologies, Faculty of Engineering, University of Florence, Florence, Italy

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanics and Industrial Technologies, Faculty of Engineering, University of Florence, Via S. Marta, 3 – 50139 Florence, Italy. email: dario.vangi@unifi.it

abstract.p: The present study is aimed at the validation of the triangle method for evaluating energy loss in vehicle collisions. The validation of the method is performed under two different points of view: first, the ability of the method to provide correct energy loss values; this was done by comparing the method results to experimental and numerical crash tests; and second, the ability of the method to produce results with a low scatter, due to the uncertainty in input data; this was done by performing a sensitivity analysis. It is clearly demonstrated that the triangle method can be used to evaluating energy losses involved in car crashes.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: In reconstructing traffic accidents it is important to estimate the kinetic energy lost due to damage inflicted on the vehicles involved in the crash. This information allows one to define the accident kinematics prior to the collision, thus allowing discrimination between solutions obtained using existing classical methods that are generally based on conservation of momentum or conservation of energy approaches. The importance of estimating energy loss in vehicle collisions has led to the development of various methodologies, all essentially variations on two main approaches:

list-item.p: CRASH3 methods, based on the measurement of crush depth, initially proposed by Campbell [1] and further developed by [2–7];
the method based on comparing equivalent energy speed values [8, 9].

sec.p: Each of these approaches has advantages and disadvantages. Methods based on the measurement of residual crush require knowledge of the stiffness of the vehicles involved in the crash; this is generally expressed in terms of the stiffness coefficients A and B. However, these coefficients are not always available for all vehicles and for all parts of a specific vehicle involved in a crash. Stiffness values are available in the literature (e.g. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) tables – www.nhtsa.gov); however, such data often only refers to American cars and the data is only classified based on either the wheelbase or mass of the vehicle. Methods based on visual comparison of the damage are not always applicable, since it is not always possible to find vehicles with a similar size, mass, and stiffness values that have undergone similar deformations (size, position, and shape of the damage).

An approach called the ‘triangle method’ has been developed to overcome these limitations [10]. This method is based on the linearization of the vehicle’s damage profile and combines the advantages of both the previously discussed approaches: it combines the simplicity of visual comparison of damage, typical of the equivalent energy speed method, with the versatility and potential of the method based on residual crush measurement.
To check the validity of a method and its good performance, generally it is required that a model:

list-item.p: is physically correct and gives correct results (effectiveness);
provides acceptable results (considering the precision usually available for the input data) and the spread due to the variability of input data is limited (efficiency).

sec.p: This paper presents the results of work performed to validate the triangle method in terms of its effectiveness and efficiency.

sec.title: 2 Theory behind the Triangle Method
sec.p: For the purpose of calculating energy loss, the deformation profiles of the vehicles involved in a crash can be represented, to a good approximation, by a straight line. Thus, the damage can be assumed to have a simplified shape, triangular or rectangular, and can be fully characterized in terms of a few shape parameters. The shape parameters are the maximum damage depth C and the damage width Ld, as a ratio to the total vehicle width L100, which form two sides of the triangle or rectangle used to approximate the damage. These parameters can be simply evaluated by visual examination of a photograph (as in the equivalent energy speed method); in other words measurements on the vehicle do not have to be performed.

When the shape parameters are known, they can be utilized to calculate the equivalent energy speed EES and then the energy loss, using equations derived by Vangi [10] that were based on the approach proposed by Campbell [1].
For rectangular damage the proposed equation is
for triangular damage it is
and for a 40 per cent offset damage shape it is
where PDOF is the principal direction of the resultant force [7] and b0 and b1 are Campbell’s coefficients.

The three equations yield a linear trend in EES value as a function of C, with different slopes and intercepts. The latter can be assumed, for all three equations, to be equal to b0 which is Campbell’s parameter without significant error. Thus, all three equations can be approximated with a unique line with slope b1, using a damage equivalent depth kC

The intercept b0 represents the speed under which no permanent deformation is obtained in a crash against a rigid barrier, and, as an indication, it can be put equal to 2 m/s. k is an appropriate shape factor to allow for the difference in slope and intercept of the different lines: k = 1 for rectangular damage, k = 0.564 for triangular damage, and k = 0.653 for the 40 per offset damage shape. Equation (4) suggests that a deformation with a generic shape can be transformed, when calculating energy loss, to an equivalent deformation with rectangular shape and depth equal to kC.

The use of the triangle method requires a value for the parameter b1 of the vehicle under study to be obtained using a similar vehicle with a reference damage for which the EES value is known. According to the shape of the reference damage, equation (4) yields

The triangle method can thus be used to evaluate energy loss without requiring knowledge about the vehicle’s stiffness coefficients; it only requires a photograph of a similar vehicle for which the EES value is known, even if the damage on the reference vehicle differs in severity and shape from that of the vehicle under examination. Once the b1 parameter is known the desired EES value can be calculated using equation (4) for the damaged vehicle under study.

sec.title: 3 Materials and Methods
sec.p: In this paper, the validity of the model is demonstrated by:

list-item.p: comparing energy loss values obtained experimentally with those obtained in numerical simulations (a good match between the energy loss value demonstrates the effectiveness of the method);
performing a sensitivity analysis to errors on the input data of the model to verify efficiency.

sec.title: 3.1 Comparison of energy loss values
sec.p: The energy loss values comparison was performed between:

list-item.p: values of energy loss obtained in experimental crash tests carried out at the University of Florence, Italy;
and values of energy loss obtained in simulation studies.

sec.p: Considering that the triangle method is a simplification of the method of Campbell, a comparison is also made with the classic Campbell’s approach, to verify how the simplifications assumed in the triangle method influence the results. The comparison was made by considering absolute and relative errors between computed and experimental values, keeping in mind the acceptable intrinsic error deriving from every real accident reconstruction.
The triangle method was applied by estimating the shape parameters of the damage for each test and then applying equations (4) and (5).

sec.title: 3.1.1 Experimental crash tests
sec.p: The experimental tests were conducted on the crash track of the Department of Mechanics and Industrial Technologies, University of Florence, Florence, Italy. The crash tests used for validation were conducted on Fiat Panda and Fiat Uno cars, model year 1992, with frontal impact against a rigid, non-deformable barrier at different speeds and with different offsets (100 per cent, 40 per cent) and in impact against a barrier inclined at 45° with respect to the vehicle’s direction of motion (see Table 1). The shapes obtained were, respectively: rectangular, 40 per cent offset shape, and triangular.

caption.p: List of crash tests and parameters

sec.p: The following instrumentation was used to acquire data during the tests:

list-item.p: Crossbow (www.xbow.com) accelerometers, model CXL100HF3, triaxial, full scale ±100g, pass band 0.3–10 000 Hz;
AGE Scientific (www.agescientific.com) 16 channel data acquisition system, sample frequency 12.5 kHz, resolution 12 bits, acquisition time 14 s in 4 Mb RAM (170 000 samples per channel);

AGE Scientific (www.agescientific.com) laser speed measurement system, time-interval measurement performed through optical sensors (LED–laser) placed on a measured base of 1 m, minimum speed 0.1 km/h;

Fastec (www.fastecimaging.com) InLine high-frame-rate video camera, model 250, frame rate 250 frames/s and 8 bit monochromatic resolution, storage of 2.184 frames in approximately 8.7 s in a 512 Mb memory;
photogrammetry performed with Nikon D50 camera, fitted with 28 mm lens calibrated by Mencisoftware (www.menci.com) and certified SIT;
Sokkia (www.sokkia.it) SET5F total station with storage capacity of 3000 points.

sec.p: The laser speed measurement system and the high-frame-rate video camera, were used to measure the vehicle speed before and after the collision.

Accelerometer data were acquired in each test and this data was used to determine the longitudinal acceleration curve over time. The accelerometers detected acceleration in the three orthogonal directions x, y, and z, and were positioned inside the car, fixed to the base of the chassis: one at the centre of gravity (behind the gearshift stick), another in the rear-seat tunnel, and the final one under the front passenger seat. The data acquired and sampled were filtered, to eliminate high-frequency noise, with a 60 Hz low-pass filter using the protocol set out in the J211 standard: Instrumentation for Impact Test - Society of Automotive Engineers International – www.sae.org.

On each vehicle, the width of the deformed area and the six deformation depths Ci were measured by means of manual measurement, according to the procedure given in [11]; the measured values are provided in Tables 2 and 3. The deformed area profiles were also measured at three different heights above the ground using a total station instrument. The manual measurements of the deformation depths were found to be in agreement to those performed with the total station instrument, with deviation on the order of one centimetre.

tr.td: Experimental deformation energy: 21 475 J (taking in to account also the friction work between car and barrier)
Experimental deformation energy: 36 316 J (taking in to account also the friction work between car and barrier)

sec.p: For each crash test, the speed of the vehicle arriving at and exiting from the collision was measured, allowing the kinetic energy loss in the impact to be evaluated as the difference between the initial and final kinetic energy values. Moreover, for each tested vehicle, the measured Ci values, as indicated in Tables 2 and 3, allow the A and B stiffness parameters to be calculated following the procedure explained in [4] and the EES values using the classic Campbell approach. Damage profiles of each vehicle are also reported in Tables 2 and 3.

sec.title: 3.1.2 Numerical simulations
sec.p: Numerical simulations were performed utilizing LS-Dyna software (www.ls-dyna.com) using a finite element model of a Dodge Neon, model year 2002. The finite element model consisted of about 270 000 shell elements with solid elements being used to describe some vehicle components such as the engine and brakes. The total mass was 1317 kg. The model was equipped with seven accelerometers to measure the deceleration. The numerical model of the vehicle is available on the internet (www.ncac.gwu.edu) and has been validated by comparison with the results obtained in an experimental 100per cent offset crash test against rigid barrier (NCAC National Crash Analysis Center, test NCAP number 2320 – www.ncac.gwu.edu). The simulations were performed to mimic a frontal impact against a rigid barrier at 20 and 30 km/h, with 100 per cent and 50 per cent offset. The calculated speed values and damage profiles for each simulation are listed in Table 4. The shape parameters of the damage were also determined and the energy loss was estimated.

sec.title: 3.2 Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: Since the final result of the triangle method depends on the estimation of the geometric parameters of the damage, it is useful to evaluate the sensitivity of the method to uncertainty in these input data.
The design of experiment (DOE) method [12] was used to obtain a complete factorial plan in which the following variables were assumed:

list-item.p: the maximum damage depth C on the reference vehicle;
the damage width Ld on the reference vehicle;
the PDOF of the reference vehicle;
the maximum damage depth C on the vehicle under study;
the damage width Ld on the vehicle under study;
the PDOF of the vehicle under study.

sec.p: Other parameters, such as b0, were not considered as input parameters of the model, since they were not considered in the simulation studies.

For each variable two levels were considered, with the following ranges: ± 5 cm for the damage depths, ± 5 per cent for the width of the front end, and ± 10° for the PDOF. The DOE approach allows the most influential parameter that affects the precision of the triangle method to be isolated, i.e. the parameter that requires the most attention in this evaluation.

The DOE-derived plan was applied in two phases following the application of the triangle method: first for the problem of determining the b1 parameter starting from the reference damage, using equation (5), then second using this b1 parameter to determine EES values for the damage under study using equation (4).

Furthermore, to evaluate the global error expected from utilizing the triangle method, a Monte Carlo simulation was performed with 100 000 random samples of the variables (a uniform distribution was used to provide the worst case), each within the uncertainty range used to perform the DOE test. Two cases were considered:

list-item.p: the worst case, with slight damage to both the reference vehicle and the one under study and a high vehicle stiffness;
the best case, with severe damage to both the reference vehicle and the one under study and a low vehicle stiffness.

sec.p: The simulation was performed utilizing triangular-shaped damage; however, the results are applicable to other damage shapes.

sec.title: 4.1 Analysis of experimental crash tests
sec.p: For each tested vehicle, the stiffness coefficients A and B were calculated using the procedure given in Neptune et al. [4], starting from the Ci measurements given in Tables 2 and 3. The mean values calculated for each vehicle and those taken from the NHTSA tables categorized in terms of the vehicle’s wheelbase are listed in Table 5. For each vehicle, the energy loss E was evaluated using Campbell’s approach, utilizing the n = 6 measurements of the Ci deformation depth

caption.p: Vehicle mean stiffness coefficient values (unit: N/m2)

sec.p: Calculations were performed utilizing both the mean stiffness parameters of each vehicle determined from the crash tests and the values taken from the NHTSA table.

When using the experimentally determined stiffness values for the coefficients A and B, the mean absolute error between the EES values calculated with the classic method and those determined by experimentation was 3 per cent, with a maximum error of 7 per cent. When utilizing A and B values taken from the NHTSA table, the mean absolute error rose up to 12 per cent, with a maximum error of 17 per cent (see Fig. 1).

caption.p: EES values (unit: km/h) calculated by Campbell’s method compared with those determined by experimentation

sec.p: To apply the triangle method, the shape parameters for the damage on each vehicle were evaluated (see Table 6). The triangle method was applied utilizing damage found in other crashes on the same car model as the reference damage. The results of this application are shown in Table 7; a comparison with the values determined experimentally is shown in Fig. 2. A comparison of the deformation energy values calculated by the triangle method and those determined experimentally demonstrated a mean absolute error of 1.1 km/h, with a maximum absolute error of 2 km/h, and a mean relative error of 2.5 per cent, with a maximum relative error of 4.5 per cent.

caption.p: Geometric parameters estimated on vehicles subjected to a crash
EES values (unit: km/h) evaluated by the triangle method
Comparison between EES values evaluated by the triangle method and those determined experimentally

sec.title: 4.2 Analysis of simulation results
sec.p: The shape parameters of the damage for each crash test were evaluated in the numerical simulations, see Table 8. The triangle method was then applied to each case, utilizing another crash test as the reference damage on each occasion. The energy loss on each vehicle was then evaluated in different ways, each starting from a different reference deformed vehicle (see Table 9). The EES values determined with the triangle method are compared in Fig. 3 with those determined in the numerical simulations. This comparison between the EES values obtained numerically and those with the triangle method, shows that the energy values estimated with the triangle method are practically identical to those determined by numerical simulation, with errors less than 1 km/h.

caption.p: Geometric parameters estimated from the results obtained for simulated crashes
EES values (unit: km/h) calculated for various cases in the numerical simulations
Comparison between EES values evaluated with the triangle method and those obtained in the numerical simulations

sec.title: 4.3 Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: The analysis of the sensitivity to uncertainty in the input data was carried out in two stages, with the aim of determining which of them showed the largest sensitivity to the input data. For the first stage, that is the estimation of the b1 parameter from reference damage, it was found that the shape of the damage (rectangular, triangular, etc.) had no effect on the sensitivity of the b1 parameter to input data.

Shown in Figs 4 and 5, by way of example, are the Pareto charts for severe damage with a triangular shape (severe damage depth C) and for slight damage (shallow damage depth C), which illustrate the influence of each variable (main effect) and of the interaction among variables on the estimation of the b1 parameter. In both cases, the most influential input data for estimating the b1 parameter was found to be the damage depth C, followed by the damage width L, and then by the PDOF value. Interaction between the parameters was of limited extent. The highest variations in the b1 parameter were found when starting from a minor damage state, where the range of the input parameters, evidently, has a greater percentage effect.

caption.p: Pareto chart for triangular-shaped damage, determined for severe damage depth: C = 65–75 cm, Lt = 65–75 per cent, PDOF = 0–20°, EES = 38.5 km/h
Pareto chart for estimating b1 for triangular-shaped damage, determined for shallow damage depth: C = 25–35 cm, Lt = 65–75%, PDOF = 0–20°, EES = 21.6 km/h

sec.p: For the second stage, that is the determination of the EES value for the damage under study starting from the b1 parameter, it was found that the shape of the damage had little influence on the sensitivity of the results to input data. For example, the Pareto chart in Fig. 6 for triangular-shaped damage shows the different influences on the estimation of EES value in terms of variations in the geometric parameters of the input.

caption.p: Pareto chart for estimating EES value for triangular-shaped damage, determined for shallow damage depths: C = 30–40 cm, Lt = 60–70 per cent, PDOF = 10–20°, b1 = 25 s−1

sec.p: Also, in this stage the damage depth C was found to be the parameter that has the greatest influence on estimation of the EES value and thus the depth C is the parameter which must be estimated with the greatest care. The severity of the damage in this case was not an influencing factor: since a fixed stiffness (expressed by parameter b1) was assumed, the link between C and EES is linear; a variation in C influences the EES value in an identical manner whether it starts from a high or a low value of C.

Bar graphs showing the frequency of deviations from the nominal EES value (i.e. the one calculated with the mean values of each variable in the two cases considered), are shown in Fig. 7. There is a deviation of +4 km/h, – 5 km/h in EES value in the best case and +6 km/h, – 9 km/h in the worst case, starting from uncertainty in the initial data of: ± 5 cm for damage depth, ± 5 per cent in the width of the front end, and ± 10° in the PDOF.

caption.p: Frequency of deviation from nominal value of EES in the best (black ■) and the worst case (grey )

sec.title: 5 Discussion
sec.p: The comparison of the triangle method with the classic Campbell’s method shows that the simplifications assumed by linearizing the damage profile do not influence the calculated EES values (Figs 1 and 2). The results obtained using Campbell’s method using experimental values of the A and B stiffness coefficients are quite similar to the ones obtained using the triangle method: they produce similar percentage errors, both mean and maximum. This confirms that several measurements of the damage depth do not improve the precision of the estimate of the EES value.

A substantial difference arises when a comparison is made with the results obtained with Campbell’s method using values for the A and B stiffness coefficients taken from the NHTSA tables. The EES values in this case are quite different from the experimental ones, and the error becomes significantly higher. This highlights one important advantage of the triangle method: the vehicle’s stiffness coefficients are required only implicitly; in fact, they are taken directly from a comparison with a reference damage state, with an arbitrary shape. This aspect makes the triangle method highly versatile, since it is sufficient to have a reference damage of any shape and severity.

The triangle method yields accurate results in comparison with the experimental ones, with the mean errors limited to 2.5 per cent of the EES values. These errors fall within the range determined for other classic methods and are generally deemed acceptable for reconstructing traffic accidents. The relationship between the variations in speed undergone by the vehicles as a consequence of the impact or between the relative collision speed and the EES value is linear [13] and thus any errors in the EES value influence errors in the aforesaid speeds to the same percentage degree. Thus, considering that in real accident reconstruction many approximations are generally assumed and that the input data are often subject to inaccuracy [14], an error of a few kilometres per hour in the evaluated EES value can be considered to be a good result.

The results of the overall sensitivity analysis indicate that, in order to minimize the final error on the vehicle’s EES value, it is advisable to utilize a reference damage that is severe in its extent, in order to minimize the error on the estimation of the vehicle’s stiffness, and to be especially careful in estimating the depth of the damage, both for the reference vehicle and for the one under study, since this is the most influential parameter in the calculation.

The geometric damage parameters C and Ld are generally estimated by subjective evaluation, although this can be done by direct measurement when the damaged vehicle is available. Obviously, this estimation is influenced by the quality of the images of the vehicle. In many cases, more precise geometric damage parameters can be obtained by comparing the photographs of the vehicle with a CAD drawing, so as to compare and ‘measure’ on the drawing the dimensions that are estimated in the photographs, as shown in Fig. 8.

caption.p: Triangular-shaped damage; diagram and measurement of geometric parameters

sec.p: The Monte Carlo simulation shows that the triangle method furnishes a good overall estimate for the EES value that is comparable to the acceptable errors in the reconstruction of real accidents, for all combinations of stiffness of the vehicle and severity of the damage, even in the case of errors in estimating the damage parameters.

sec.title: 6 Conclusions
sec.p: This paper demonstrates that the triangle method can be confidently used to evaluate a vehicles’ kinetic energy loss in a road traffic accident. Its performance was evaluated in terms of two different aspects: the effectiveness and the efficiency of the method.

The validations of the effectiveness and accuracy of the method were performed by comparing the results with EES values determined in experimental crash tests and numerical simulations. The good outcome of this comparison demonstrates the ability of the method to calculate correctly the energy loss values.

It has been shown that when the data available concerning the A and B stiffness coefficients of the reference car are not completely representative of the situation under examination, the triangle method yields better results than the classic method of comparison of EES values or CRASH3-like methods.

The efficiency of the method was proven by a sensitivity analysis of the results to errors in the input data. The analysis of the sensitivity indicates that in order to minimize the final error on the vehicle’s EES value, it is advisable to utilize a severe damage extent as the reference damage, in order to minimize the error on the vehicle’s stiffness, and to be especially careful in estimating the depth of the damage, both for the reference vehicle and for the one under study, since it is the most influential factor in the computation.
